introduction.p: In , rectangles have been drawn to approximate the area below y=f(x) and above the x-axis between x=1 and x=9 using a Riemann sum.

figure.caption: Rectangles approximating the area below y=f(x) between x=1 and x=9.

image.description: Graph of a function f(x) on Cartesian axes, increasing and concave up. A light blue shaded region lies beneath the curve from about x = 5 to x = 8 and above the x-axis, with horizontal reference lines indicating approximate function values. The curve starts near y = 5 at x = 0 and rises to above y = 30 by x ≈ 9.

statement.p: Calculate \Delta x, the width of each subinterval.

Does the diagram illustrate a left, right, or Midpoint Riemann sum? In the Riemann sum \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^4 f(x_k^*) \Delta x, give an expression for x_k^* in terms of k. Then, calculate the value of the Riemann sum.

answer.p: This is a left Riemann sum whose value is 88.

solution.p: This is a left Riemann sum. \displaystyle x_k^* = 1+2(k-1) = -1+2k. The value of the Riemann sum is \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^4 f(x_k^*) \Delta x = 4(2) + 6(2) + 12(2) + 22(2) = 88.

statement.p: For \Delta x = 2, calculate the value of \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^4 f(1+2k) \Delta x which also estimates this area. Then, illustrate the value or this Riemann sum with a figure similar to that shown in .

figure.caption: A right Riemann sum approximating the area below y=f(x) between x=1 and x=9.

image.description: Graph of a function f(x) on Cartesian axes, increasing and concave up. Light red shaded rectangles approximate the area under the curve from about x = 4 to x = 9, extending from the x-axis up to the graph. Horizontal step edges indicate a right-endpoint style approximation. The curve rises from near y = 5 at x = 0 to above y = 30 by x ≈ 9.

statement.p: A better approximation is likely to come from a midpoint sum. Use sigma notation (as in (c)) to describe a midpoint Riemann sum with n=4. Use the sketch in as desired. Start by computing expressions for \Delta x and x_k^*.

figure.caption: A midpoint Riemann sum approximating the area below y=f(x) between x=1 and x=9.

image.description: Graph of a function f(x) on Cartesian axes, increasing and concave up. Light red shaded rectangles lie beneath the curve from about x = 1 to x = 9, representing a left-endpoint Riemann sum approximation of the area under f(x). The curve starts near y = 5 and rises to above y = 30 toward the right.

solution.p: \Delta x = 2 and x_k^* = 2k so the midpoint Riemann sum is \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^4 f(2k)(2)
